ranked_diseases.explanation: Alport Syndrome is commonly associated with chronic kidney disease and proteinuria due to defects in type IV collagen, and it is a leading cause of these symptoms in younger adults.
Fabry Disease can cause proteinuria and progressive kidney disease due to a buildup of globotriaosylceramide in renal cells. This can lead to chronic kidney disease.
IgA Nephropathy is a common cause of glomerulonephritis that can cause proteinuria and chronic kidney disease, typically detected by hematuria and proteinuria.
Type IV Collagen-related Nephropathy includes Glomerular basement membrane diseases, similar to Alport Syndrome, which can cause proteinuria and chronic kidney disease.
Thin Basement Membrane Nephropathy causes persistent hematuria, mild proteinuria, and can progress to chronic kidney disease in some cases.
